patterns: fever, cough, sore throat, runny nose, muscle aches
responses: You might have the flu. Consider seeing a healthcare provider for proper diagnosis and treatment.

patterns: runny nose, sneezing, sore throat, mild cough, mild fever
responses: You might have a common cold. Rest and hydration are usually sufficient for recovery.

patterns: nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, stomach cramps, fever
responses: You might have a stomach virus. Ensure you stay hydrated and consider consulting a doctor if symptoms persist.

patterns: itchy eyes, sneezing, runny nose, hives, swelling
responses: You might be experiencing an allergy. Avoiding allergens and taking antihistamines may help.

patterns: severe headache, nausea, sensitivity to light, dizziness
responses: You might be having a migraine. Rest in a quiet, dark room and consider over-the-counter pain relief.

patterns: facial pain, nasal congestion, headache, cough, fever
responses: You might have sinusitis. Drinking plenty of fluids and using a humidifier may provide relief.

patterns: itchy rash, red spots, fever, tiredness, loss of appetite
responses: You might have chickenpox. Keep the rash clean and consult a healthcare provider for advice.

patterns: red eyes, itchy eyes, watery discharge, swollen eyelids
responses: You might have conjunctivitis (pink eye). Avoid touching your eyes and consult a doctor for treatment.

patterns: persistent cough, mucus production, wheezing, chest discomfort
responses: You might have bronchitis. Rest and staying hydrated are important. Consider seeing a doctor if symptoms persist.

patterns: cough with phlegm, fever, chills, shortness of breath, chest pain
responses: You might have pneumonia. Seek medical attention immediately for a proper diagnosis and treatment.

patterns: increased thirst, frequent urination, fatigue, blurred vision
responses: You might have diabetes. It's important to consult a healthcare provider for a blood sugar test and further advice.

patterns: headache, dizziness, shortness of breath, chest pain
responses: You might have hypertension. Regular check-ups and lifestyle changes can help manage blood pressure.

patterns: wheezing, shortness of breath, coughing, chest tightness
responses: You might have asthma. Using an inhaler and avoiding triggers can help manage symptoms.

patterns: stomach pain, nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, bloating
responses: You might have gastritis. Avoiding spicy or acidic foods and consulting a doctor can help.

patterns: itchy skin, red rashes, dry skin, inflammation
responses: You might have eczema. Moisturizing your skin and avoiding irritants may provide relief.

patterns: dry, scaly skin patches, itching, redness, inflammation
responses: You might have psoriasis. Topical treatments and managing stress can help control symptoms.

patterns: persistent cough, weight loss, night sweats, fever
responses: You might have tuberculosis. It's crucial to get tested and treated under medical supervision.

patterns: yellowing of skin, dark urine, abdominal pain, nausea, fatigue
responses: You might have hepatitis. Consult a healthcare provider for testing and appropriate treatment.

patterns: hoarseness, sore throat, dry cough, difficulty speaking
responses: You might have laryngitis. Resting your voice and drinking warm fluids can help.

patterns: painful sores, itching, burning sensation, swelling
responses: You might have herpes. Antiviral medications can help manage outbreaks.

patterns: painful rash, blisters, itching, fever, headache
responses: You might have shingles. Consult a healthcare provider for antiviral medications and pain relief.
